doc.field: Top-level talks with Bluem about employment policies

Leading representatives of the unions and business associations have met with Federal Labour Minister Bluem to discuss federal employment policies. The meeting was held to develop an action plan on unemployment, which the federal government had committed itself to at an EU employment summit meeting last November. Bonn has turned its attention specifically to youth unemployment and to the re-integration of those who have been out of the labour market for long periods. The government does not plan to release any new monies into its employment programs, according to vice-chairman of the German Federation of Unions, Engelen-Kefer. Bluem does, however, want to extend the government's program benefitting the long-term unemployed.
Kohl warns against drastic increases in gasoline prices

Chancellor Kohl has warned against a drastic increase in the cost of gasoline, saying that a price of 5 DM/litre, as the Greens are calling for, would put jobs and investments at risk. Kohl was speaking at the celebratory opening of the new headquarters of auto manufacturer Opel in Ruesselsheim, Hesse. At the same time, Kohl called for continued reductions in noise and air pollution from autos. Opel's chairman of the board, Hermann, said that he stood behind Standort Deutschland (Germany as a base for economic activity), and pointed out that the company had spent over DM 4 billion just on the development of its new model, the Astra. He added that Opel was planning further investments.
First round of negotiations in public sector arbitration

Arbitration has begun in the contract dispute in the public sector. The member of the arbitration team for the employees, an SPD politician, Koschnik, plans to table a suggested settlement in five days. He judged the overall situation as being difficult, saying "The ice is pretty thin, and the cow is pretty fat." Following the first round of negotiations, the arbitrators expressed cautious optimism. Koschnik said the talks showed there was a possibility of success, although "the devil hides in the details". He added that both sides agreed on the principle of a consensual solution, and wanted to avoid a strike. The other arbitrator, former Rhineland-Palatinate Premier Wagner, said the plan was to try to put together a package deal acceptable to both sides. He also said that the sticking points seemed to be employment security , sick pay continuance, and the issue of extra old age security. The arbitration talks resume on Monday.
Contract negotiations in Eastern German construction industry adjourned

Contract talks for the 380,000 workers in the Eastern German construction industry have been adjourned. There has been absolutely no convergence of view points between the two sides, a spokesman for the employers said in Berlin. The negotiations are scheduled to resume in Dresden in early April. The union Construction, Agriculture, Environment is calling for wage increases of 4 percent and more job security. The employers see no leeway for pay increases, and feel that structural changes must be discussed.
1997 was record year for Lufthansa

The German airline Lufthansa increased its turn-over by 11 percent, to DM 23 billion, in 1997. Profits were up by 45 percent to DM 800 million. It was the best year in the airline's history. None of Lufthansa's areas of enterprise experienced a financial loss.
Kanther still rejects halting deportation of Kosovo-Albanians

Federal Internal Affairs Minister Kanther has reiterated his assessment that there is presently no reason to implement a general halt on deportations of Albanians from the Yugoslavian province of Kosovo. Speaking on Deutschlandfunk radio, Kanther suggested especially that such a move could send a signal that would induce many others to go to Germany, hoping to then remain in the country. The minister also accused several of the German states with SPD-led governments of abdicating the joint responsibility for deporting foreigners. Kanther emphasized Albanians from Kosovo would not be deported if their lives were threatened.
Government expects unemployment numbers to drop

The federal government is expecting economic growth of between 2.5 and 3 percent for the current year. The information comes from the 1998 Economic Report which was passed by the cabinet today. Federal Economic Minister Rexrodt told journalists in Bonn that the number of unemployed was going to sink for the first time in four years and, in December, would be about 200,000 less than at the end of 1997. The SPD and Alliance/Greens said it was unclear where the upturn was supposed to come from, and that the predicted growth was insufficient to create new jobs.
Inflation in Germany may be less than believed

According to a study by the German Central Bank, prices are increasing significantly more slowly than official statistics indicate. The Central Bank's Economic Research Group in Frankfurt explained that the monthly cost-of-living index may over-estimate the actual inflation rate by more than 3/4 of a percent. According to the group , the largest source of error was that the Federal Statistics Office failed to take into full account changes in quality or the introduction of new models of products; also changes in consumer behaviour were not calculated in quickly enough. According to the Bank's reasoning, inflation in Germany is approaching zero.
Police find boy's body in artificial lake

Police discovered the body of a boy in an artificial lake near Peine, Lower Saxony yesterday evening. They are assuming it to be the body of 13-year-old Markus Wachtel, missing since Saturday. The body was found drifting on the water, naked , and missing several limbs. A total of 70 police officers searched the shoreline for clues until early evening. The specialized "scene of the crime investigation team" from the Federal Criminal Office was flown in and worked until after dark. It was only after that that the body was pulled from the water and taken to the Medical College in Hanover.
Cases of Sudden Infant Death down substantially

The number of cases of Sudden Infant Death has dropped by almost half since 1990. Eight years ago, 1300 cases were recorded; in 1996, it was only about 690. Experts credit a public awareness campaign over the last several years with the drop. According to a study from the University of Muenster, sleeping on the stomach is often the cause of Sudden Infant Death.
Tennis: Graf and Kiefer advance

Steffi Graf is the first player to advance to the semi-finals in the tennis tournament being held in Indian Wells, California. She defeated Byelorussia's Natasha Zvereva 6:3 and 6:0. Nicolas Kiefer reached the eighth-finals with a victory over American player Washington.
